articles.title: California reimagines high school: how one innovative campus is shaping the future of learning
articles.summary: BY THE OPTIMIST DAILY EDITORIAL TEAM Our Best of 2025 Education stories reflect a growing global commitment to reimagining how we learn, teach, and grow. These five highlights explore new models, inspiring individuals, and bold ideas that bring equity and creativity into classrooms and beyond. At CART High near Fresno, there are no bells, no […]
articles.content:
BY THE OPTIMIST DAILY EDITORIAL TEAM

Our Best of 2025 Education stories reflect a growing global commitment to reimagining how we learn, teach, and grow. These five highlights explore new models, inspiring individuals, and bold ideas that bring equity and creativity into classrooms and beyond.

At CART High near Fresno, there are no bells, no fights, and no hallways echoing with chaos. Instead, students carry laptops through bright, spacious corridors on their way to classes in biotechnology, forensics, and digital marketing. It looks and feels nothing like a traditional public high school, and that’s precisely the point.

CART, short for Center for Advanced Research and Technology, could represent the future of education in California. As Linda Darling-Hammond, president of the State Board of Education, put it: “The big, old-fashioned factory model of high school—where students run from class to class with a locker as their only stable point of contact—is not succeeding. We need to overhaul the whole idea of what high school can be.”

Now, a new statewide pilot program from the California Collaborative for Educational Excellence aims to do just that. Backed by $10 million in state funding, the initiative invites districts to redesign high school and middle school learning, focusing on flexibility, real-world experience, and stronger connections between students, teachers, and communities.

A century-old system ready for change

Public high schools, as we know them, are barely a century old. Born from early 20th-century industrial ideals, they were designed around efficiency. As many of us know, this resulted in standardized classes, 50-minute periods, and a rigid unit system known as the Carnegie unit. But modern research in adolescent development shows teenagers learn best through autonomy, hands-on projects, and collaboration.

“It should be a joy to go to school every day,” Darling-Hammond said. And at CART, it seems to be. Students don’t memorize facts for tests; they immerse themselves in topics that matter to them. Instead of racing through fragmented classes, they spend three hours per day in interdisciplinary “labs” where English, science, and art intersect.

This shift is already producing results. Attendance hovers near 100 percent, discipline issues are rare, and over 90 percent of students score proficient in English. Principal Rick Watson says educators from around the world visit to study CART’s model. “Comprehensive high schools don’t work for some B, C, D students,” he explained. “The students have potential, but they’re disconnected. They’re desperate for a different model of education.”

Teaching that sparks curiosity

At CART, the focus is on engagement and deep, not rote, learning. English teacher Emily Saeteurn explains: “We work really hard to get kids to see the bigger picture of why they’re learning what they’re learning. We want them to have that ‘aha!’ moment.”

Biotechnology students read The Andromeda Strain and The Martian before writing their own science fiction stories based on real genetic concepts. In law and policy, teens read Othello and Hamlet before staging mock trials of Shakespearean characters. The approach makes academics tangible and relevant.

Senior Madelyn Quiroga says she struggled at her traditional high school but thrives at CART. “At my other school, they just throw stuff at you and never really explain it. Here, they actually teach us, and it’s all stuff we actually want to know,” she said. “Like when I hear someone talk about CRISPR, it’s like, ‘Oh, I know something about that.’”

Her classmate Audrey Riede, studying law, says she now hopes to become a defense attorney. “CART is way better than normal school,” she said. “The teachers aren’t just trying to get you to pass; they really want to make you think.”

Challenges ahead for reform

The state faces major hurdles in expanding CART’s success. Colleges still rely on the A-G course requirements and traditional letter grades for admissions, leaving little flexibility for innovative coursework. The Carnegie unit, which ties credits to time spent in class rather than mastery, remains deeply embedded in both high school and university systems.

Even the Carnegie Foundation has urged reforms, advocating for progress-based measures over time-based ones. But as of now, most higher education institutions remain reluctant to change.

Still, advocates like Russlynn Ali, head of the XQ Institute and former U.S. Department of Education official, believe the momentum is shifting. “There are young people today who’ve graduated from high school but can’t calculate the tip on a split bill or grasp the main idea in an op-ed piece,” she said. “The case for change is unmistakable.”

A model of possibility

CART’s success story began 25 years ago as a partnership between Clovis Unified and Fresno Unified, designed to help struggling students connect learning to real careers. Today, it serves 1,000 juniors and seniors each year, nearly 80 percent from low-income families. The school’s popularity continues to grow. Last year, more than twice as many students applied as there were spots available.

As California prepares to announce the winning redesign proposals, CART’s bright yellow halls stand as a living example of what education could be: a place where learning feels relevant, curiosity thrives, and every student, from the A student to the “C kid”, finds a reason to show up.

articles.personality_title: California's CART High shows a new way to learn and succeed
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Traditional high schools in the U.S. were designed about 100 years ago to be like factories, with students moving quickly from one class to another and learning mostly by memorizing. Experts now say this old model doesn’t work well because teenagers learn better when they have more freedom and work on hands-on projects.

**What happened** – Near Fresno, California, CART High (Center for Advanced Research and Technology) offers a different style of education. Instead of bells and strict schedules, students spend long blocks of time in labs that combine subjects like science, art, and English. They learn by doing real-world projects, such as writing science fiction based on genetics or acting out trials from Shakespeare plays. This approach has helped students stay interested, attend school regularly, and perform better academically. CART serves about 1,000 juniors and seniors, most coming from low-income families.

**Impact** – CART’s model shows that school can be a place where students enjoy learning and connect what they study to real life. Attendance is almost perfect, discipline problems are rare, and over 90% of students meet grade-level standards in English. This success has caught the attention of educators worldwide and inspired a $10 million California state program to redesign schools with similar ideas. CART especially helps students who struggle in regular schools by giving them meaningful and engaging learning experiences.

**What's next step** – California is testing new ways to change high schools across the state based on CART’s ideas. However, challenges remain, such as how colleges accept students and how schools measure learning by time instead of understanding. Still, with growing support, this approach might spread and change how many students learn in the future.

**One-sentence takeaway** – CART High’s hands-on, flexible learning shows a practical path to making high school more engaging and effective for all students.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le lycée CART en Californie montre une nouvelle façon d'apprendre et de réussir
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les lycées traditionnels aux États-Unis ont été conçus il y a environ 100 ans comme des usines, avec des élèves passant rapidement d’une classe à une autre et apprenant surtout par cœur. Les experts disent aujourd’hui que ce modèle ancien ne fonctionne pas bien car les adolescents apprennent mieux en ayant plus de liberté et en réalisant des projets pratiques.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Près de Fresno, en Californie, le lycée CART (Centre de Recherche et Technologie Avancée) propose un style d’enseignement différent. Au lieu de sonneries et d’horaires stricts, les élèves passent de longues périodes dans des laboratoires qui combinent des matières comme les sciences, l’art et l’anglais. Ils apprennent en réalisant des projets concrets, comme écrire des histoires de science-fiction basées sur la génétique ou jouer des procès tirés des pièces de Shakespeare. Cette méthode aide les élèves à rester motivés, à venir à l’école régulièrement et à mieux réussir. CART accueille environ 1 000 élèves de première et terminale, dont la plupart viennent de familles à faibles revenus.

**Impact** – Le modèle de CART montre que l’école peut être un lieu où les élèves aiment apprendre et relient leurs études à la vie réelle. La présence est presque parfaite, les problèmes de discipline sont rares, et plus de 90 % des élèves atteignent les niveaux requis en anglais. Ce succès a attiré l’attention des enseignants dans le monde entier et inspiré un programme californien de 10 millions de dollars pour réinventer les écoles avec des idées similaires. CART aide particulièrement les élèves en difficulté dans les écoles classiques en leur offrant des expériences d’apprentissage intéressantes et utiles.

**Prochaine étape** – La Californie teste de nouvelles façons de transformer les lycées dans tout l’État en s’inspirant des idées de CART. Cependant, des défis restent, comme la façon dont les universités acceptent les élèves et comment les écoles évaluent l’apprentissage par le temps au lieu de la compréhension. Malgré cela, avec un soutien croissant, cette approche pourrait se répandre et changer la manière dont beaucoup d’élèves apprennent à l’avenir.

**Résumé en une phrase** – L’apprentissage pratique et flexible du lycée CART montre une voie concrète pour rendre le lycée plus motivant et efficace pour tous les élèves.

articles.title: Was our earliest ancestor a knuckle-dragger, or did it walk upright?
articles.summary: Did Sahelanthropus, which lived 7 million years ago, walk on two legs like a modern human? It's complicated
articles.content:
Did Sahelanthropus , which lived 7 million years ago, walk on two legs like a modern human? It's complicated

Sahelanthropus fossils (centre) compared with a chimpanzee (left) and a human (right) Wiliams et al., Sci. Adv. 12, eadv0130

A long-running and bitterly fought dispute over whether the earliest known hominin had a knuckle-walking gait, like chimpanzees, or walked upright, like humans, may have been settled – but not everyone is convinced.

Scott Williams at New York University and his colleagues say that reanalysis of fossil remains of Sahelanthropus tchadensis shows it had at least three key anatomical features that together show that it was our earliest known hominin ancestor to be bipedal.

It has, however, been a lengthy journey to reach this point.

The 7-million-year-old fossil skull, teeth and a jawbone of Sahelanthropus tchadensis were first described in 2002, following their discovery in the desert region of Chad, in north-central Africa. With a pronounced brow ridge and small canines, the ancient animal was immediately recognised as being unlike great apes.

The anatomy of the skull showed that it likely sat directly on top of the spine, similar to the condition seen in other upright-walking, bipedal hominins.

Subscriber-only newsletter Sign up to Our Human Story Each month, Michael Marshall unearths the latest news and ideas about ancient humans, evolution, archaeology and more. Sign up to newsletter

Then, in 2004, French scientists identified a femur – a thigh bone – and ulna – a forearm bone – that had also been found alongside the skull fossils in Chad as belonging to Sahelanthropus. However, it wasn’t until 2020 that the researchers published their findings, arguing that the femur was curved in a way that resembled that of a non-bipedal great ape.

The debate has swung back and forth ever since. For example, in 2022, a research team including Franck Guy and Guillaume Daver, both at the University of Poitiers in France, argued that certain anatomical traits on the femur indicated bipedality. In 2024, meanwhile, Clément Zanolli at the University of Bordeaux in France and his colleagues argued that Guy and Daver’s team was wrong, because those supposedly bipedal anatomical traits could also be seen in non-bipedal great apes.

Williams, the lead author of the most recent study, says he entered this scientific fray with a “fairly ambiguous” opinion of Sahelanthropus.

He and his colleagues first looked at the point on the femur where the gluteus maximus muscle had once attached to the bone. They found that this attachment point looked similar to those seen on hominin thighbones.

They also analysed the size and shape of the femur and ulna. Although both are similar in size to the equivalent bones in chimpanzees, their proportions were more aligned with those of a hominin.

Finally, they identified a previously overlooked feature in the Sahelanthropus femur called a “femoral tubercle”.

“I actually initially identified it by touch, then confirmed it visually using 3D scans of the fossil,” says Williams. “It’s a small bump that sits only where the femoral tubercle would be; the area is smooth in apes and other non-bipeds, but it has a major function.

“It serves as the attachment point of the iliofemoral ligament, the largest and most powerful ligament in the human body. That ligament is loose when we’re sitting but tightens around the femoral head to hold it in the hip joint when we stand and walk, preventing our torso from falling backwards or sideways.”

Williams, however, doubts the new research will fully settle the argument about how Sahelanthropus moved.

“We’re fairly convinced that Sahelanthropus was an early bipedal hominin at this point, but I’d be foolish to think we ended the debate.”

Guy and Daver, who argued that the hominin was bipedal in 2022, released a joint statement to New Scientist in response to the new paper.

“It not only confirms our initial interpretations of the adaptations and locomotion of the earliest hominin Sahelanthropus but also puts forward new arguments supporting its terrestrial habitual bipedalism, despite an overall morphology that remains close to that of a great ape,” the researchers say.

But they also acknowledge that only the discovery of new remains will conclusively end the debate.

John Hawks at the University of Wisconsin-Madison says he agrees with the new findings and says they point to a complicated origin for the hominin lineage.

“I think it may be misleading to imagine that Sahelanthropus are all hominin or all ape,” Hawks says. “Our evolution started as a fuzzy, gradual set of changes towards more upright posture and movement, and Sahelanthropus had features that help us to understand those changes.”

Zanolli, who has strongly argued that Sahelanthropus was not bipedal, disputes the new paper’s findings, saying that “most, if not all, of the results point toward similarities with the African great apes”.

“In my view, this new study simply confirms that Sahelanthropus long bones resemble those of the African great apes, and that it was probably behaving in ways that could range anywhere in between those of a chimpanzee and a gorilla, but clearly differed from the habitual bipedalism as known in Australopithecus and Homo,” says Zanolli.

Journal reference: Science Advances DOI: 10.1126/sciadv.adv0130

This discovery has broad implications for the general public's understanding of human origins and evolutionary biology. The article focuses on a single topic with detailed scientific context and presents a meaningful breakthrough in paleoanthropology, which is inspiring and intellectually uplifting.
articles.personality_title: New study finds earliest human ancestor likely walked on two legs
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists have long debated how Sahelanthropus tchadensis, a 7-million-year-old ancestor of humans, moved. Some thought it walked on all fours like chimpanzees, while others believed it walked upright like modern humans.

**What happened** – A team led by Scott Williams at New York University reexamined Sahelanthropus fossils found in Chad. They studied the thigh and forearm bones using 3D scans and found key features, including a special bump on the thigh bone where a strong ligament attaches. This bump helps support upright walking by stabilizing the hip.

**Impact** – This discovery adds strong evidence that Sahelanthropus was the earliest known ancestor to walk on two legs. It changes how scientists understand the start of human walking and shows that our ancestors began standing upright earlier than some thought.

**What's next step** – Researchers say more fossils are needed to fully settle the debate. Future discoveries could provide clearer proof about how these early ancestors moved and help explain how walking on two legs evolved.

**One-sentence takeaway** – New research suggests Sahelanthropus, our earliest known ancestor, most likely walked upright, marking an important step in human evolution.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une nouvelle étude montre que le plus ancien ancêtre humain marchait probablement sur deux jambes
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques débattent depuis longtemps de la façon dont Sahelanthropus tchadensis, un ancêtre humain vieux de 7 millions d’années, se déplaçait. Certains pensaient qu’il marchait à quatre pattes comme les chimpanzés, d’autres qu’il marchait debout comme les humains modernes.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Une équipe dirigée par Scott Williams de l’Université de New York a réexaminé les fossiles de Sahelanthropus découverts au Tchad. Ils ont étudié les os de la cuisse et de l’avant-bras avec des scans 3D et ont trouvé des caractéristiques clés, dont une petite bosse sur l’os de la cuisse où un ligament puissant s’attache. Cette bosse aide à soutenir la marche debout en stabilisant la hanche.

**Impact** – Cette découverte apporte une forte preuve que Sahelanthropus était le plus ancien ancêtre connu à marcher sur deux jambes. Cela change la compréhension scientifique du début de la marche humaine et montre que nos ancêtres se sont mis à marcher debout plus tôt qu’on ne le pensait.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs expliquent que d’autres fossiles sont nécessaires pour clore le débat. De futures découvertes pourraient apporter des preuves plus claires sur la façon dont ces ancêtres se déplaçaient et aider à comprendre l’évolution de la bipédie.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Une nouvelle recherche suggère que Sahelanthropus, notre plus ancien ancêtre connu, marchait probablement debout, marquant une étape importante dans l’évolution humaine.
articles.personality_title_es: Nuevo estudio encuentra que el ancestro humano más antiguo probablemente caminaba sobre dos piernas
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos han debatido durante mucho tiempo cómo se movía Sahelanthropus tchadensis, un ancestro humano de hace 7 millones de años. Algunos pensaban que caminaba en cuatro patas como los chimpancés, mientras que otros creían que caminaba erguido como los humanos modernos.

**Qué pasó** – Un equipo liderado por Scott Williams de la Universidad de Nueva York volvió a examinar los fósiles de Sahelanthropus encontrados en Chad. Estudiaron los huesos del muslo y del antebrazo con escaneos 3D y encontraron características clave, incluyendo un pequeño bulto en el hueso del muslo donde se une un ligamento fuerte. Este bulto ayuda a sostener la marcha erguida al estabilizar la cadera.

**Impacto** – Este descubrimiento aporta una fuerte evidencia de que Sahelanthropus fue el ancestro conocido más antiguo que caminaba sobre dos piernas. Cambia la forma en que los científicos entienden el inicio de la marcha humana y muestra que nuestros ancestros comenzaron a caminar erguidos antes de lo que se pensaba.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores dicen que se necesitan más fósiles para resolver completamente el debate. Descubrimientos futuros podrían ofrecer pruebas más claras sobre cómo se movían estos primeros ancestros y ayudar a explicar cómo evolucionó la marcha bípeda.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Una nueva investigación sugiere que Sahelanthropus, nuestro ancestro conocido más antiguo, probablemente caminaba erguido, marcando un paso importante en la evolución humana.

articles.title: Oulu and Trencin are Europe’s new Capitals of Culture
articles.summary: This year, Europe’s Capitals of Culture are located in the far north of the continent and in Slovakia. In doing so, they are succeeding, among others, a city in Saxony.
articles.content:
This year, Europe’s Capitals of Culture are located in the far north of the continent and in Slovakia. In doing so, they are succeeding, among others, a city in Saxony.

Oulu/Trencin (dpa) – The Finnish city of Oulu and the Slovak city of Trencin have been the new European Capitals of Culture since the turn of the year. Oulu, considered the northernmost major city in the EU, and Trencin (German: Trentschin), located around 2,000 kilometers to the south, have thus, among others, succeeded the Saxon city of Chemnitz, which held the title last year together with the Slovenian-Italian twin border city Nova Gorica/Gorizia.

The two cities have each put together an extensive program of events for 2026. In Oulu, the year as Capital of Culture will be ushered in with an opening festival from January 16 to 18, whose program ranges from concerts and acrobatics to car tuning and the Finnish national sport of ice hockey.

In Slovakia, the ceremonial opening will take place from February 13 to 15. The organizers then want to transform the renovated historic old town of Trencin into an open cultural stage full of music, art and social gatherings. The city, just a two-and-a-half-hour drive from Vienna, intends to carry the title of Capital of Culture with great pride – and, together with the surrounding region, to inspire both Slovak and foreign guests.

EU cultural initiative

The title of European Capital of Culture may be held each year by two or three cities from different countries of the EU or from closely associated states such as Norway. The EU initiative is intended to highlight Europe’s cultural diversity and to honor the culture and art characteristic of each region.

The first Capital of Culture was Athens 40 years ago. Four German cities have also held the title since then: first West Berlin in 1988, then Weimar in 1999, Essen together with the Ruhr region in 2010, and then Chemnitz in 2025. In 2027 it will be the turn of Liepaja in Latvia and Évora in Portugal. (January 1)

articles.personality_title: Oulu and Trencin named Europe’s Capitals of Culture for 2026
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Every year, the European Union selects one or more cities as Capitals of Culture. This title highlights the unique culture and art of each city and encourages people to learn about different parts of Europe.

**What happened** – For 2026, the cities of Oulu in Finland and Trencin in Slovakia were chosen as Europe’s Capitals of Culture. Oulu is the northernmost big city in the EU, while Trencin is located about 2,000 kilometers to the south. Both cities have planned many events, such as concerts, art shows, and sports, to celebrate throughout the year. Oulu’s opening festival will be from January 16 to 18, featuring music and ice hockey, and Trencin will start its celebrations from February 13 to 15 with activities in its historic old town.

**Impact** – This title brings attention to these cities and their regions, encouraging visitors from other countries to explore their culture and history. It also helps local people come together to celebrate their traditions and create new experiences. The program promotes cultural diversity across Europe by showing how different places have their own special stories and talents.

**What's next step** – Over the year, Oulu and Trencin will host many cultural events to share their heritage with visitors and locals. After 2026, the title will move to new cities in Latvia and Portugal in 2027, continuing the tradition of celebrating Europe’s wide variety of cultures.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Oulu and Trencin will spend 2026 sharing their unique cultures as Europe’s Capitals of Culture, inviting everyone to experience their art, history, and community spirit.
articles.personality_title_fr: Oulu et Trencin nommées Capitales européennes de la culture 2026
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Chaque année, l’Union européenne choisit une ou plusieurs villes comme Capitales européennes de la culture. Ce titre met en valeur la culture et l’art uniques de chaque ville et encourage les gens à découvrir différentes régions d’Europe.

articles.title: Euro now also currency in Bulgaria
articles.summary: When the clocks rang in 2026, Bulgaria introduced the euro as its currency. Now there are only six of the EU’s member states, among them Sweden, that do not have the euro.
articles.content:
When the clocks rang in 2026, Bulgaria introduced the euro as its currency. Now there are only six of the EU’s member states, among them Sweden, that do not have the euro.

Stockholm – Bulgaria has introduced the euro as its currency, almost 20 years after the country joined the EU. The transition from the Bulgarian currency lev took place at the turn of the year.

Several of the country’s governments have advocated that the country should join the euro, in the hope that it will stimulate the economy. Bulgaria is the EU’s poorest member state. But there is concern among Bulgarians that the introduction may lead to higher prices and increase political instability in the country.

With Bulgaria’s entry into the euro, only six of the EU’s 27 countries now remain outside the monetary union: Sweden, Poland, Czechia, Hungary, Romania and Denmark.

(2 January)
articles.reasoning: Bulgaria's adoption of the euro represents a significant economic integration step within the EU, potentially stimulating economic growth and stability for its population. This change impacts a broad public and marks progress in European unity and economic cohesion. While concerns exist, the article focuses on the meaningful policy shift and its potential positive effects.
articles.personality_title: Bulgaria adopts the euro, joining most of the EU in a big currency change
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Bulgaria has been a member of the European Union (EU) for nearly 20 years but until now used its own money called the lev. Many countries in the EU use the euro, a shared currency meant to make trade and travel easier.

**What happened** – At the start of 2026, Bulgaria officially switched from the lev to the euro. This means people and businesses in Bulgaria now use the euro for all their money needs. Bulgaria is the poorest country in the EU, and several past governments pushed for this change to help the economy.

**Impact** – Using the euro can make it easier for Bulgaria to trade with other EU countries and attract investment. It could help the country’s economy grow and become more stable. However, some people worry that prices might go up or that the change could cause political problems. Still, this switch shows Bulgaria becoming more connected with the rest of Europe.

**What's next step** – Now that Bulgaria uses the euro, only six EU countries remain without it: Sweden, Poland, Czechia, Hungary, Romania, and Denmark. These countries might watch Bulgaria’s experience to decide if they want to join the euro in the future.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Bulgaria’s move to the euro marks a major step in joining the EU’s economic group, aiming to boost growth and strengthen ties with Europe.
